name: 5-bromoindole
Reason: 5-bromoindole has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a bromine atom, which increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the formation of hydrogen bonds with the indole ring. The bromine atom can also participate in dipole interactions, which raises the melting point. The indole ring itself has a melting point around 100°C, due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions. The bromine atom introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10°C. The presence of a bromine atom also increases the melting point due to the formation of hydrogen bonds with the indole ring, estimated at around +10°C.
